page.title: 16Harvesting hops in Stonegate
page.content:
When the hops are ripe,usually in the first week of September,they are cut down by a man using a swop.The cut bines are taken by a tractor with a special trailer to a hop-picking machine.This machine picks the hops from the bines and places them in bags called pokes.They are then taken to an oast house,dried in kilns and pressed into bags called pockets.A pocket is six feet long,and when filled with dried,pressed hops will weigh 80kg. A fair crop should produce twelve pockets per acre.From the oast house the hops are taken to the brewery for making into beer.
Witherenden Farm has ten acres of hop garden.
